In this study, CuX zeolite supported Mn and/or Ce oxides catalysts were synthesized by combining ion exchange and impregnation methods, and the zeolite X was generated using blast furnace slag (BFS). Doping Mn-Ce oxides onto the CuX catalyst, which has excellent resistance to SO2 +H2O, improved the catalyst's activity for NH3-SCR at lower temperature. In addition, electron transfer from Mn4+ to Ce3+ and Cu2+ was enhanced, and the concentration of isolated Cu2+ and chemisorbed oxygen species was higher in the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst. Also, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst provided excellent SCR activity because of its high acid capacity, which allowed it to provide extra acid sites, and its high redox ability, which enhanced the re-oxidized and re-reduced cycles. Additionally, produced sulfates on the catalyst surface after SO2 and H2O poisoning might occupy Cu2+ active sites and affect the SCR process by competing with acid sites, nitrate species and intermediates on the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Low-temperature NH3-SCR Blast furnace slag Zeolite X Cu2+ active sites Mn-Ce oxides Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The nitrogen oxides (NO x ), emitted from the emission of the flue gas in the industrial plants, are extremely harmful to both human health and environments [1–3]. Traditional commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts were unsuitable for applications in the low-temperature condition (<300 °C), because the active component V was a poisonous and hazardous material that would cause secondary pollution [4–6]. Accordingly, it was crucial to search for a catalyst that could handle low-temperature industrial flue gas while also being friendly to the environment. Recently, zeolite-based catalysts for the treatment of various flue gases have become a hot topic. Among them, zeolite X with a faujasite (FAU) framework structure, a large surface area and superior acidity, has been widely applied for the removal of elemental mercury, the methanation of CO2 and the absorption of N2O, SO2 and H2S, among other applications [7–10]. Nevertheless, zeolite X was rarely reported as a catalytic support in the NH3-SCR process. According to our prior research [11], X zeolite doped Mn-Ce catalyst exhibited superior low-temperature NH3-SCR activity compared to ZSM-5 and Beta supported catalyst. In addition, BFS was one among the solid wastes produced during the iron production process, which consisted SiO2 and Al2O3 [12], and as our recent study demonstrated [13], it could be utilized for the zeolite X preparation, hence conserving resources and treating waste via waste. Due to the fact that zeolite X had a low NO conversion rate, the active component had to be doped in order to boost its SCR performance. The transition metals oxides, such as Mn, Cu and Fe, etc., have shown great promise for use in low-temperature SCR catalyst, because they readily lose their outer electrons and exhibit excellent redox characteristics [14–17]. In particular, our prior studies found that Mn-based catalysts provided superior low-temperature SCR performance [18–20]. The single Mn-based catalyst had some drawbacks, however, has issues like poor SO2 resistance and low N2 selectivity. In order to increase the catalytic activity of Mn-based catalysts, an additional active component was frequently added. Yao et al. [21] demonstrated that the addition of Ce and Mn on Cu-SSZ-39 zeolite catalyst had superior acidity and catalytic activity. On the other hand, Copper-exchanged zeolite catalysts also have shown remarkable activity for SCR reaction. Various studies [22,23] found that the catalytic efficiency and stability of Cu-exchanged catalysts were affected by the varied shape of the copper site on the Cu-exchanged zeolites, as well as by the abundance of unoccupied sites on these catalysts and their greater SCR activity. However, the Cu-exchanged zeolite X catalysts applied in NH3-SCR process was seldom reported and their reaction mechanism was still not clear. Based above mentioned, in this study, a series of CuX supported Mn or Ce catalysts were prepared using the combination of ion exchange and impregnation method to remove NO via NH3-SCR technology and the utilized zeolite NaX was generated from blast furnace slag in a cost-effective manner. This study focused on the effect of Cu sites and the Mn and Ce additions on the properties of the catalysts, as well as the correlation between the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity of the catalysts. Additionally, the reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR over Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst was discussed using in situ DRIFT analysis. 2 Experimental section The blast furnace slag (BFS) from Baoshan Iron & Steel Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China) was pretreated to produce Si-Al gel, following the procedure outlined in our earlier studies [13,24,25]. According to our most current research [13], zeolite NaX was then synthesized via the seed method. Next, we constructed zeolite CuX catalysts doped with Mn or Ce oxides by ion exchange combining with impregnation method, and named as Mn/CuX, Ce/CuX, and Mn-Ce/CuX, respectively. The specific preparation methods of all catalysts were presented in the Supporting Information (SI). 3 Results 3.1 SCR catalytic performance NO conversion of all catalysts increased with increasing temperature (at 75–150 °C) and remained nearly 100% from about 150 °C to 300 °C, whereas the N2 selectivity of all catalysts presented a decreasing tendency with the increasing temperature at 75–300 °C ( Fig. 1a-b), and the catalytic activity of CuX catalyst was also illustrated in Fig. S1. For CuX catalyst, NO conversion was about 40% at 75 °C and climbed to ca. 100% at 200 °C [24]. NO conversion of Mn/CuX catalyst was around 40% at 75 °C, increased to almost 100% at 150 °C, and then remained stable, whilst Mn/CuX catalyst displayed the lowest N2 selectivity at the entire reaction temperature range. As for Ce/CuX catalyst, it showed the lowest NO conversion rate at the temperature range of 75–150 °C but the denitration rate also remained nearly 100% after 150 °C. In addition, Ce/CuX catalyst had the best N2 selectivity across the whole reaction temperature range of the process. Compared with Mn/CuX and Ce/CuX catalysts, NO conversion of Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst was the superior in the temperature range of 75–300 °C, which was nearly 60% at 75 °C, increasing to nearly 100% at slightly less than 150 °C, and remained stable thereafter. While the N2 selectivity of Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst was comparable to that of Ce/CuX catalyst, which was around 100% at 75 °C and gradually declined to approximately 60% at 300 °C. In addition, N2O and NH3 concentrations of the three catalysts were shown in Fig. S2, it could be found that Mn/CuX catalyst had the highest N2O concentration, but the Ce/CuX and Mn-Ce/CuX catalysts had nearly the same N2O concentration. And the NH3 concentration of Mn/CuX, Ce/CuX and Mn-Ce/CuX catalysts increased between 75 and 175 °C, and then decreased over 225 °C. It could be indicated that Ce/CuX catalyst had the outstanding N2 selectivity in comparison to Mn/CuX catalyst. Additionally, co-doping Mn and Ce on catalyst could can concurrently boost NO conversion and N2 selectivity. The apparent activation energy (Ea) and reaction rates (r) were depicted using An Arrhenius plot, and the findings are given in Fig. S3. Ea values of Mn/CuX, Ce/CuX and Mn-Ce/CuX catalysts were 6.9KJ/mol, 6.8KJ/mol, 4.3KJ/mol, respectively. In addition, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst had the highest r value of the three catalysts from Table S1, demonstrating that, when compared to single doping of Mn or Ce on CuX support, Mn-Ce co-doping could significantly reduce the energy barrier and enhance the NH3-SCR reaction rate. The effect of SO2 and/or H2O on SCR activity of Mn/CuX, Ce/CuX and Mn-Ce/CuX catalysts was also examined, as depicted in Fig. 1c-d. According to Fig. 1c, the NO conversion of the Mn/CuX catalyst declined progressively to about 68% when 100 ppm SO2 was supplied, stayed stable for 10 h, and recovered to approximately 72% when SO2 was removed. The catalytic activity of the Ce/CuX catalyst decreased to around 78% in the presence of SO2 and remained unchanged after SO2 was eliminated. However, NO conversion of Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst remained nearly unchanged for 10 h after SO2 addition and remained stable after SO2 removal. This demonstrated that Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst exhibited superior SO2 resistance and stability, whereas Mn/CuX catalyst presented the poorest SO2 resistance. The effect on SCR performance for all catalysts when 100 ppm of SO2 and 5% H2O concurrently entered the reaction system was shown in Fig. 1d. When SO2 and H2O were introduced, the NO conversion of Mn/CuX catalyst dropped from nearly 99% to about 47% and remained constant for 10 h; similarly, the NO conversion of Ce/CuX catalyst dropped from nearly 99% to about 50% and remained constant for 2.5 h, then declined to nearly 40% and stayed unchanged for 7.5 h. However, the NO conversion rate decreased from 99% to 86% and remained relatively stable for 10 h on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst, which exhibited the greatest resistance to SO2 and H2O. When SO2 and H2O were removed, the NO conversion of Mn/CuX and Ce/CuX catalysts remained essentially unchanged, but the NO conversion of Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst recovered to nearly 97%. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts 3.2.1 structural and morphology of catalysts XRD patterns of Mn/CuX, Ce/CuX and Mn-Ce/CuX catalysts are presented in Fig. 2. It was discovered that the diffraction peak positions in the vicinity of 2θ= 6.8°, 15.5°, 18.5°, 20.2°, 23.4°, 26.8° and 30.5°, which were belonged to the (111), (331), (511), (440), (533), (642) and (660) crystal faces of zeolite X (JCPDS NO.12–0228), respectively, indicated that the zeolite X structure of all catalysts remained almost stable after preparing process, and all the catalysts were synthesized successfully. There were also four diffraction peaks attributed to the CuO phase at 2θ= 35.5°, 38.9°, 48.8° and 61.5° (JCPDS NO.48–1548), demonstrating that the CuO phase on the surface of all catalysts was formed and moved on the surface of all catalysts throughout the calcination process due to an excess of Cu species. Noted that, the lowest intensity of CuO phase peaks was seen on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst, showing that the co-doping of Mn-Ce components could inhibit the formation of CuO phase. No diffraction signal was seen for oxides of manganese and cerium, pointing to well scattered Mn and Ce species throughout the catalysts. Crystallize size was also estimated and reported in Table S2, with the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst displaying a smaller crystallize size than both the Mn/CuX and Ce/ CuX catalysts. The SEM images and element distributions of Mn/CuX, Ce/CuX and Mn-Ce/CuX catalysts are exhibited in Fig. 3. The microstructure of Mn/CuX catalyst (in Fig. 3a) was revealed to be regular octahedral. Based on the mapping results (Fig. 3b1), the Cu species exhibited some agglomeration, but the Mn species were developed uniformly over Mn/CuX catalyst. On the Ce/CuX catalyst (in Fig. 3b), the phenomenon of particle agglomeration was also observed. But the Cu species were concentrated over Ce/CuX catalyst, whereas Ce species were scattered uniformly, as depicted in Fig. 3b1. As shown in Fig. 3c, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst had octahedral morphology, and the Cu, Mn, and Ce species were more evenly distributed on the zeolite X support. In comparison to Mn/CuX and Ce/CuX catalysts, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst possessed more active sites due to its uniform particle size and highly dispersed active components, which led to its higher catalytic activity. 3.2.2 Surface chemical states characterization From the survey depicted in Fig. 4a, it was determined that the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst had the strongest Si and Al spectra. The spectra of Cu 2p (as shown in Fig. 4b) exhibited three major peaks at approximately 933 eV, 945 eV and 953 eV, correlating to Cu 2p3/2, shake-up satellite peak and Cu 2p1/2, respectively [26,27]. The Cu 2p3/2 spectra were fitted into two peaks at 932.6 eV and 934 eV, which was corresponding to the distinctive peak of Cu+ species and isolated Cu2+ species relating to the framework oxygen atoms of the zeolite X, respectively [27–30]. A shake-up satellite peak appeared at about 945 eV, owing to the charge transfer between the Cu 2p orbitals surrounding ligand oxygen and 3d orbitals [31]. According to the researches [26,32], isolated Cu2+ species were discovered in the zeolite lattice as an isolated state and served as an active site during the catalytic process [33]. Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst had a larger concentration of isolated Cu2+ species (around 33%) in Table S3, confirming that the Cu species were the predominant presence of isolated Cu2+ species without severe clustering, hence contributing to the high low-temperature SCR activity. It could be noticed that there were three fitting peaks at around 533.5 eV, 531.6 eV and 529.5 eV on spectra of O 1 s (Fig. 4c), which were assigned to chemisorbed oxygen or weakly bonded oxygen species (containing O2- and O-), chemisorbed oxygen species (O2-) and lattice oxygen species (O2 -), and denoted as Oγ, Oα, Oβ, respectively [34,35]. It was known that the chemisorbed oxygen species were more active than lattice oxygen species in the oxidation process due to their greater mobility [11,36]. Therefore, more reactive oxygen species could significantly enhance catalytic activity at low temperature by maintaining the metal cation in a more oxidized state. And the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst contained the largest concentration of Oα species in Table S3, promoting its superior SCR activity. As seen in Fig. 4d, the spectra of Mn 2p had two broad peaks about 643 eV and 654 eV, which were assigned to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2, respectively. There were three well-defined fitting peaks in the Mn 2p3/2 spectrum that correspond to Mn4+ (644.7 eV), Mn3+ (642.5 eV) and Mn2+ (640.5 eV) species, respectively [5,15,37]. The higher value state species of Mn4+ and Mn3+ were more active than Mn2+ species in NH3-SCR reaction, which were contributed to facilitation of the “fast SCR” reaction (NO+NO2 +2NH3 =2 N2 +3 H2O) [38]. Additionally, the higher Mn4+ and Mn3+ species concentration of the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst in Table S3 compared to the Mn/CuX catalyst may have contributed to the increased NH3-SCR activity of the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst. The two spin-orbital multiplets (880–920 eV) corresponding to Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 were fitted into eight peaks on the Ce 3d spectra, which were designated as u, u’, u’’, u’’’ and v, v’, v’’, v’’’, respectively, with the bands marked as u′ and v′ were assigned to Ce3+, and the bands labeled as u, u’’, u′’’ and v, v’’, v′’ were attributed to Ce4+ [11,30]. In addition, it could be observed that the chemical state of Ce4+ species on catalysts surface was dominated and only a part of Ce3+ species. Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst had a greater percentage of Ce3+ species (27%) than the Ce/CuX catalyst (21%) in Table S3, where the Ce3+ species enhanced the number of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, hence boosting the NH3-SCR reaction [19]. Furthermore, it was discovered that an increase in Ce4+ species concentration could promote redox cycles according to Eqs.(1)–(2), leading to the formation of additional Cu2+ species and Mn4+ species [19,39–41]. (1) Cu + + Ce 4 + ↔ Cu 2 + + Ce 3 + (2) Mn 3 + + Ce 4 + ↔ Mn 4 + + Ce 3 + As described in Fig. 4f, EPR spectroscopy was used to identify the oxygen vacancies in the Mn/CuX, Ce/CuX, and Mn-Ce/CuX catalysts. The symmetrical signal (g=2.08) was discovered to have been created by unpaired electrons trapped in an oxygen vacancy [42,43]. As indicated by the XPS spectra above, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst had a higher spin concentration and peak intensity than the Mn/CuX catalyst, indicating that the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst contained more oxygen vacancies, which was consistent with the above analysis of XPS spectra analyses. 3.2.3 Acidic and redox performance From NH3-TPD curves in Fig. 5a, the peaks at about 114–124 °C were attributed to weak acidity of NH3 physical absorption, the peaks at about 165–390 °C were ascribed to medium acidity, and the peaks at about 526–593 °C belonged to strong acidity [18,44]. As depicted in Fig. 5b, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst possessed a higher total surface acidity than the Mn/CuX and Ce/CuX catalysts, indicating that the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst had more acidic sites for the NH3-SCR reaction. Moreover, the adsorption and desorption performance for NH3 species in the temperature of 35–300 °C over Mn/CuX, Ce/CuX and Mn-Ce/CuX catalysts were conducted via in situ DRIFTS experiments, as shown in Fig. 5c. The bands related to coordinated adsorbed NH3 species on Lewis acid sites (1610 cm−1 and 1260 cm−1) and NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1390 cm−1) could be observed [38,45]. The intensity of NH3 adsorption band declined with the increasing temperature for all the catalysts, and all the band shifted to lower wavenumber, owing to the broken of hydrogen bonds on the chemisorbed NH3 species [46]. In addition, the peaks belonging to Lewis acid sites were stronger than those of Brønsted acid sites, and the total amount of Lewis acid sites was more than that of the Brønsted acid sites as well. For Mn/CuX catalyst, the band attributed to Brønsted acid sites disappeared at around 200 °C, while the bands belonged to Lewis acid sites still remained at 300 °C, indicating that the loss of Brønsted acid sites on Mn/CuX catalyst. As for Ce/CuX catalyst, the bands ascribed to Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites were still present at 200 °C, however, the band attributed to Brønsted acid sites disappeared at 300 °C, suggesting the loss of Brønsted acid sites only at higher temperature on Ce/CuX catalyst. For Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst, the negative band at around 1182 cm−1 was observed, which was assigned to the asymmetrical and symmetrical bending vibrations of coordinative NH3 on Lewis acid sites [38]. Furthermore, the bands assigned to Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites remained at 200 °C, but the band belonged to Brønsted acid sites disappeared at 300 °C, indicating the adsorbed NH3 species on Lewis acid sites were more stable even at higher temperature. The broad curve in H2-TPR (Fig. 5d) was fitted into three peaks for the catalysts: the peak α (240–264 °C) was resulted from the reduction of CuO species to Cu0, the peak β (313–324 °C)was related to the reduction of Cu2+ species on the hydroxyl group of zeolite X, the peak γ (379–386 °C) was attributed to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ ions located in lattice zeolite X, and all the Cu+ ions in the catalyst to Cu0 over 400 °C [22,47,48]. According to research [49], the reductions of MnO2 to Mn2O3, Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, and Mn3O4 to MnO were at around 200–500 °C, and the redox process of surface-capping oxygen of CeO2 was at around 400 °C, which were coincided the redox peaks of copper species. It could be found that the order of redox temperature was Mn-Ce/CuX < Mn/CuX < Ce/CuX, indicating the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst exhibited the best redox ability at lower temperature among the three catalysts. Among the three catalysts, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst consumed the most H2 of the three catalysts (Fig. 5e), indicating a high redox capacity. The bigger peak area for the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst indicated a higher concentration of isolated Cu2+ species, which was consistent with the XPS results. 3.3 In situ DRIFTS studies 3.3.1 NO + O2 co-adsorption on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst The introduction of NO + O2 for 2 min resulted in the appearance of many bands at 1000–2000 cm−1 in Fig. 6a. As evidenced by band at 1915 cm-1, which was attributable to nitrate species on Cu2+ active sites, and SCR reaction process could be aided by an isolated Cu2+ speck [31]. Multiple bands assigned to bidentate bridging nitrate (M-O2-NO) at around 1600–1650 cm−1, bidentate chelating nitrate (M-O2NO) at about 1500–1570 cm−1, monodentate nitrate (M-O-NO2) at around 1480–1530 cm−1, and the free-NO3 - species of antisymmetric N-O stretches at 1317–1400 cm−1 were observed [18,50–52]. In addition, the band at 1320 cm−1 was assigned to bidentate nitrite (M-O2N) and the band at 1575 cm−1 belonged to bridging nitrite (M-O2-N) were observed [18,20]. The intensity of all the bands increased as time progressed, furthermore, the weak band (1190 cm−1) belonged to cis-N2O2 2- species were detected when NO + O2 introduced for 10 min. The bands attributed to nitrate species on Cu2+ active sites (1915 cm−1), bidentate bridging nitrate (1600 cm−1), bridging nitrite (1575 cm−1), bidentate chelating nitrate (1520 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1480 cm−1) and free-NO3 - (1315 cm−1) species diminished with the increasing temperature and approximately nearly vanished at 300 °C (Fig. 6b) [18,50–52]. Furthermore, monodentate nitrate species vanished at 75 °C and exhibited the poorest stability, whereas the bidentate chelating nitrate, bidentate bridging nitrate and free-NO3 - species were more stable, and persisted even at 275 °C. 3.3.2 Reactions between NH3 and NO+O2 species on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst The intensity of the bands belonged to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1430 cm−1) and coordinated adsorbed NH3 species on Lewis acid sites (1610, 1240, 1200 cm−1) declined gradually when NO+O2 was injected in Fig. 6c, at the same time, the bands assigned to nitrate species on Cu2+ active sites (1915 cm−1), bidentate bridging nitrate (1600 cm−1), bridging nitrite (1575 cm−1), bidentate chelating nitrate (1520 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1480 cm−1), bidentate nitrite (1320 cm−1) and free-NO3 - (1320 cm−1) species could be detected immediately [18,23,32,50,53], and the strength of these nitrate species increased with the time of NO+O2 exposure. This indicated that the NO molecular absorbed on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst surface to form nitrate species and then combined with the pre-absorbed NH3 species, thereby the reaction of Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst followed Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism [1,32]. Furthermore, NH2NO species on Cu2+ active sites were also observed at around 1520 cm−1 [31], resulting in -NH2 species and gas NO molecules and playing an important role in the SCR reaction, showing the reaction of Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst obeyed Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism as well [1,32]. Noted that the strength of the bands assigned to bidentate bridging nitrate (1650 cm−1), bidentate chelating nitrate (1520 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1480 cm−1) and free-NO3 - (1320 cm−1) species decreased immediately in Fig. 6d. Meanwhile, when NH3 was exposed for a longer period of time, the intensity of the bands that belonged to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1430 cm−1) and coordinated adsorbed NH3 species on Lewis acid sites (1610 and 1240 cm−1) [18,23,50]. In addition, the band assigned to NH4NO3 (1420 cm−1) were found, and a negative band belonged to cis-N2O2 2- species at around 1190 cm−1 could be detected [20,31], suggesting the generation of NH4NO3 intermediate and the consumption of cis-N2O2 2- species, respectively. It indicated that the reaction of Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst mainly followed L-H mechanism. The strength of the bands for NH3 + NO + O2 desorption decreased as the temperature increased (Fig. S4), and the NH4NO3 species desorbed completely at around 200 °C, indicating poor stability. 3.3.3 In situ DRIFTS studies on Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst The Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst displayed the excellent SO2 or/and H2O resistance during 13 h, where the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst exposed SO2 and H2O was marked as Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst, and the in situ DRIFTS study of Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst was conducted, as represented in Fig. 6e-h. Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst for NH3 adsorbed were shown in Fig. 6e, the bands attributed to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1530 cm−1), coordinated adsorbed NH3 species on Lewis acid sites (1610, 1240, 1190 cm−1), and chelating sulfate complexes (SO x 2-) at 1080 cm−1 were detected, and the intensity of all the bands increased with the time of NH3 adsorption [18,23,47,54,55]. Furthermore, the negative bands belonged to surface sulfate (M-SO4 2-) at 1375 cm−1 and surface sulfite (M-SO3 2-) at 1347 cm−1 were observed, suggesting the consumption of the surface sulfate and sulfite species [54–56]. It was observed that the strength of the bands belonged to Lewis acid sites (1610 and 1240 cm−1) and NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1530 cm−1) declined gradually when NO+O2 was exposed (Fig. 6f and Fig. S4a) [18,23,50], and the negative bands attributed to Lewis acid sites (1610 and 1240 cm−1) and NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1530 cm−1) appeared after NO+O2 exposed for 10 min, indicating that the absorbed NO species reacted with the pre-absorbed NH3 species, and consumed the pre-absorbed NH3 species. Moreover, the negative bands belonged to surface sulfate (1375 cm−1) and surface sulfite at about (1347 cm−1) were detected, where the sulfate species also formed new reaction sites to absorb the NO species and join the reaction, resulting in the consumption of surface sulfate and sulfite species and the reduce of nitrate amount. In addition, there were only two bands belonged to free-NO3 - (1317–1400 cm−1) and cis-N2O2 2- species (1174 cm−1) on Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst [18,50–52], and the kinds of nitrate species of Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst were less than those of Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst. Which suggested that when SO2 or/and H2O was introduced, the formation of nitrate on the catalyst was inhibited, which seriously affected the SCR catalytic reaction, thus reducing the SCR catalytic reaction rate. The bands belonged to free-NO3 - (1317–1400 cm−1) and chelating sulfate complexes (SO x 2-) at 1080 cm−1 were found on NO+O2 adsorption (Fig. 6g) [22,46,50,51], and the strength of these bands increased over the time. In addition, the negative bands belonged to bidentate bridging nitrate (1600–1650 cm−1), surface sulfate (1375 cm−1) and surface sulfite (1347 cm−1) were observed [23,54,55], suggesting the consumption of surface sulfate and sulfite species and the bidentate bridging nitrate species when NO+O2 was introduced. It could be found that when NH3 was purged, the intensity of the bands belonged to free-NO3 - (1317–1400 cm−1) and chelating sulfate complexes (1190 cm−1) declined and finally disappeared in Fig. 6h and Fig. S4b [23,54,55], while the bands belonged to Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites appeared and the intensity of these bands increased with the time of NH3 exposed. It is possible that L-H mechanism may have been involved in the reaction of absorbent NH3 with nitrates that had already been absorbed, according to the results of this study. Due to the fact that the Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst possessed less acid sites, nitrate species, and intermediate types than the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst, the SCR reaction rate may be slower with the Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst. An additional indication that the Cu2+ active sites may be occupied by sulfurate and sulfurfite species on the catalyst surface was the absence of any peak corresponding to any species of nitrate, indicating that the sulfate and sulfite species on catalyst surface might occupy the Cu active sites and reduce the SCR catalytic activity. 4 Mechanism discussion The absorbed NH3 species (as stated in Eqs.(3)–(5)) on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst, including coordinated adsorbed NH3 species (on Lewis acid sites) and NH4 + species (on Brønsted acid sites), were more steady than those on Mn/CuX and Ce/CuX catalysts. More stable at higher temperatures were the coordinated adsorbed NH3 species on Lewis acid sites compared to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites than the latter. In addition, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst possessed good redox properties. And Mn-Ce/CuX had a higher α peak area than other catalysts, indicating that it included a greater number of isolated Cu2+ species to provide more active sites. Besides, the nitrate species on Cu2+ active sites were generated on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst and the formation process followed Eqs.(9)-(11) . Moreover, the re-oxidized cycle and re-reduced cycle were included in standard NH3-SCR reaction, Cu2+ species were reduced to Cu+ species by NO and NH3 in the reduction half-cycle, at the same time, Cu+ species were oxidized to Cu2+ species by NO and O2 in the oxidation half-cycle. Interestingly, the coordinated NH3 species on Lewis acid sites was consumed faster than the NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites in the first 8 min, indicating that the NH3 species on coordinated Lewis acid sites were more active than the NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites. Additionally, the NH2NO species were detected, indicating that the reactions followed “E-R” pathways (as shown in Eq. (12)). Since then, the bands corresponding to nitrate and nitrite species have emerged, and their intensity has increased over time in accordance with the L-H mechanism of reaction. When NH3 species reacted with pre-absorbed NO+O2 species, it could be found that the bands assigned to coordinated NH3 species and NH4 + species appeared and the intensity of the bands attributed to nitrate and nitrite species declined, and the cis-N2O2 2- species were consumed. However, the band belonged to NH4NO3 species appeared and the signal of the band heightened as time passed. As can be seen from this, the L-H mechanism, as given in Eqs. (13)-(14). Coordination NH3 species on Lewis acid sites over Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst was more active than that of Mn/CuX and Ce/CuX catalysts, showing that the co-addition of Mn and Ce on CuX catalyst might boost acidity, which was compatible with the NH3-TPD findings. The in situ DRIFTS study of Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst exhibited that the amount of acid sites on Mn-Ce/CuX and Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalysts was nearly identical, while the types of nitrite and nitrate on Mn-Ce/CuX-S catalyst were less and the actives sites of Cu2+ species were not observed, indicating that the sulfate and sulfite on catalyst surface might occupy the Cu2+ active sites and reduce the SCR activity. An illustration of the co-doping effect of Mn-Ce and Cu active sites on the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst was shown in Fig. 7. The Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst's NO conversion rate was maximum between 75 °C and 150 °C, and it increased to almost 100% above 150 °C. When SO2 and H2O were introduced for 10 h, Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst remained exceptionally high, at roughly 86%, and recovered to 97% when SO2 and H2O were removed, whereas the NO conversion of Mn/CuX catalyst and Ce/CuX catalyst were only approximately 47% and 40%, respectively, and remained unaltered when SO2 and H2O were stripped away. Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst also had more isolated Cu2+ species and chemisorbed oxygen species, allowing more NO and NH3 species to be absorbed on Cu2+ active sites and improving the catalytic oxidation capacity. Further to that, electron transfer around active species on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst could facilitate in the redox recycling and the generation of oxygen vacancies. Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst had higher acid capacity, which provided more acid sites, as well as higher redox ability to enhance the re-oxidized and re-reduced cycles. Moreover, the generation of intermediate nitrate species and NH2NO species on Cu2+ active sites was critical in the SCR reaction, and Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst produced more types of nitrite and nitrate species than Mn/CuX and Ce/CuX catalysts. What’s more, after SO2 and H2O poisoning, the acid sites, nitrate species and the types of intermediates on Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst reduced, and the formation of sulfate and sulfite on catalyst surface may occupy the Cu2+ active sites and influence the SCR reaction to some extent. Because of its low cost and great deNO x performance, Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst generated from blast furnace slag waste is a promising alternative for effective waste management. coredata.dc:description: In this study, CuX zeolite supported Mn and/or Ce oxides catalysts were synthesized by combining ion exchange and impregnation methods, and the zeolite X was generated using blast furnace slag (BFS). Doping Mn-Ce oxides onto the CuX catalyst, which has excellent resistance to SO2 +H2O, improved the catalyst's activity for NH3-SCR at lower temperature. In addition, electron transfer from Mn4+ to Ce3+ and Cu2+ was enhanced, and the concentration of isolated Cu2+ and chemisorbed oxygen species was higher in the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst. Also, the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst provided excellent SCR activity because of its high acid capacity, which allowed it to provide extra acid sites, and its high redox ability, which enhanced the re-oxidized and re-reduced cycles. Additionally, produced sulfates on the catalyst surface after SO2 and H2O poisoning might occupy Cu2+ active sites and affect the SCR process by competing with acid sites, nitrate species and intermediates on the Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Low-cost Mn-Ce/CuX catalyst from blast furnace slag waste for efficient low-temperature NH3-SCR
